REVIEW: Apr 2 2005	Great Value	We researched alot before making reservations and found reviews here to be mixed, but decided to try the La Quinta. We will go back again! Arriving at 10:30 am well before checkin time, there was no problems getting our bags held for us so we could get going places. For just over $100, the location can't be beaten. Everything was great. Our room on the fourth floor above the main entrance was not noisy. The staff all seemed polite and helpful. The bar on the rooftop was rather quiet, but the Empire State Building is right there to gaze at over a nightcap. Our room was clean and average size for Manhattan. Bathroom was great with plenty of hot water. The WiFi and cable TV worked fine and both elevators worked fine. The free continental breakfast was good. There is a good subway station with in one block and Penn Station with all the main lines and Madison Square Garden are just 3 blocks away! Macy's and the Empire State Building are just over a block away too! We will recommend this hotel to anyone in the hundred dollar price range and will stay there again.

Mar 25 2005	La Quinta A Good Bet	From the reviews on this site, my boyfriend and I were braced for a ramshackle room and rude staff, but we were prepared to take a chance because we got a good rate. Maybe we were lucky, but I wish I had known what I know now: this place is perfectly fine -- a good bet. We had a corner room with a king-size bed on the twelfth floor, and it was clean and reasonably comfy. The bathroom appeared to be brand-new, and the shower was nice and hot. The staff were perfunctory when we checked in, but friendly and fast when we called down to request things. I'm extremely picky, and I'd say this is a solid budget hotel that you can pick without any worries.

Mar 23 2005	LaQuinta Hotel Great Hotel for the Price	Stayed at the LaQuinta Hotel on 32nd & Broadway. Was quite pleased with the Hotel. We had rooms 510 & 511, 4 in one room and 3 in the other. Room 511 was a corner room and was even larger than Rm. 510. Both rooms were quite large and very clean. Sheets were changed daily (we marked them so we would know). We paid $99.00 for the 1st night and $109.00 for the second. WE book these rooms about 4-5 weeks prior to our trip by calling the Applecore Hotel directly. When we originally booked them, the price was $149.99 for each night. I checked the website daily. At one point the prices came down to $119.00 / night. I quickly called the hotel and asked for that price. A week before the trip I again checked the website and saw the room was down to $99.00 for the 1 day of our visit & 109.00 for the second. Again I called and asked for the lower rate. The staff was pleasant and very willing to give us the lower rate. So .... continue to check the price even after the room is reserved! Did breakfast at the hotel. Was very nice to have that to start our day, & it saved $$$$ not having to buy breakfast for everyone. Consisted of bagels, donuts, toast, fruit, several kinds of cereal, & of course coffee & juices. Since we got up early, we never had a problem with crowds in the breakfast area and we never had to wait for an elevator. We had no view from our window ( just the wall of another building). However, be sure to visit the bar on the top floor to see the beautiful view of the Empire State building.This was a great hotel and I would definitely stay there again. Even tho many on this website do not like the Penn Station area, we found it to be close to everything and very good.

Mar 21 2005	Great Place to Stay	Just returned from a 4-day stay and I must tell you, we had a very good experience. I was a little hesitant because of the elevator problems in the past, but we didn't have a problem in the least. The location couldn't have been better. Close to subway transportation and PENN Station. Not a bad walk to Time Square and very close to the Empire State Building. For the money, this IS your best buy. I recomend this place and hope to return in the near future.VickiOrange, TX

Mar 15 2005	fab hotel	we stayed at the la quinta for a week and its a fab hotel,clean comfortable,big rooms,own bathroom and a good breakfast,great location,any problems fixed straight away,what more could you ask for!great rates too!

Mar 14 2005	Great Place	This place was great!!! You cant beat the price or the location. The rooms were small but very clean. For the amount of time you spent in the room it really doesnt matter how big it is. The hallways smelled kind of funky, but remember your in the middle of NYC, not the cleanest place in the world. And besides, how much time do you spend in the hallway? I would deff. stay at this place again.

Mar 14 2005 	Don't waste your money	We registered for this hotel specifically because of its wifi claim. We are two graduate students who wanted to focus on work and use the Internet to do research. We called ahead and got a guaranteed room and were assured the wifi worked. When we arrived we were told the wifi hadn't worked for over two days. Additionally, we could not get our money back. we also had no where else to go as it was late at night. The hotel smelled really bad, as though there were dead animals in the walls. The hallways and lobby smelled the worst. The people at the front desk made no apologies for the lack of wifi service, nor for the fact that the reservations clerk did not tell us the truth. The room was incredibly tiny. The continental breakfast was the usual stale bagels and dry cereal. But in addition, the coffee was admittedly the worst, worst hotel coffee I have ever had. Do not spend your money on this hotel. There are plenty of other terrific deals in New York City.

Mar 13 2005	Great Location	Hi My boyfriend and I stayed at this hotel from March 4-9, 2005. We received a great rate and also got discounted when using our AAA card. The hotel is in a perfect location. Walking distance to times sqaure, fifth avenue, central park and other attractions. There is also a subway on the corner if you wanted go to other areas.The hotel does offer a free continental breakfast consisting of donuts, bagels, toast, orange juice, apple juice, instant oatmeal and fruit.The rooms were very small, but clean. Sometimes there wasn't any hot water so we had to take cold showers. This only happened twice out of our five nights. If you require basic amenties at a reasonable price, this is the hotel for you!!

Feb 17 2005 	Loved it!	We first checked into (and left!)another hotel around the corner and were afraid of what we would find here. I was pleasantly surprised. The hotel was in a great location and looked nice inside. Clean, nice room...great price. It was small, but it IS NY.The hallway smelled badly like fish-but I didnt spend much time in the hallway. The front desk staff was so nice and apologetic that the first hotel was so bad. They called us a great car servicee in the morning at a discount rate so we could ride to the airport in style. I will DEFINITELY stay here again!

Feb 16 2005	What do you expect?	This is a centrally located hotel in Manhattan. It costs $99 a night. You could be forgiven for expecting a slum for this price. What you get is a clean, good sized hotel, with friendy staff (especially the concierge) and a free breakfast.So it smells a bit like an old persons home, you have to queue some days for breakfast (you are getting it for free), the lifts can be a bit slow if you are above the 4th floor. Like I said ealier this is a $99 centrally located Manhattan hotel. If you can't put up with these small inconveniences, pay more for a "better" hotel. But be warned having stayed in "better" hotels, you may be disappointed when you find more inconveniences there!Overall this is an excellent hotel for the money. If you are an uptight kind of person, you may not appreciate this hotel. If you are relatively relaxed about travelling and see your hotel as a base from which to explore, choose this hotel, you won't be disappointed

Feb 16 2005	Crackin' little hotel!	We have just returned from a 6 night stay in this hotel. The location is FABULOUS! Just one block from Macy*s, Empire State Building etc and there is a subway station at the end of the street (2 mins walk). Times square is about 5-10 mins walk. The hotel is surrounded by places to eat- a fab deli at the end of the road, a Burger King, CVS pharmacy, Pizza Petes (v friendly), Wendys etc. The road itself is the chinese/thai area so if you like this type of food there are lots of restaurants to choose from. Opposite and upstairs is an internet cafe (pink sign, I think) which was $3 for a half hour.The rooms are clean with everything you need.. they were cleaned daily with fresh towels. It was a smallish room but you just sleep there! The bed was comfy and the TV massive. There was a desk, side tables, long mirror, wardrobe with iron & ironing board, TV unit, bathroom with shower and bath, soap, shampoo, shower gel and hairdryer...as I said everything you need! You can get interactive movies and games for when you are really tired and can't be bothered going out. The breakfast is fab & free- cereal, hot & cold drinks (English Tea!), bread, bagels, toaster and donuts. Also a microwave and fresh fruit. Free newspapers in here too.There was always plenty to choose from although go before 9am as between 9am & 10am it was packed full. Also front desk provides free security deposit boxes.A few minor issues...they never have enough money to change travellers cheques but there is a place just up the street who charge $5.50 per $100 or Macy*s will change them free (Floor 1 1/2 by the cafe). We had an issue with our loo which didnt flush properly and we reported it at the desk & via the complaints card but it did not get resolved- not a major issue.All in all, a great little hotel. We would stay again as everything is within walking distance which is what you need for a short stay. Would recommend it to anyone.

Jan 29 2005	I recommend this hotel!	Why do I give it an above average rate? People! Be realistic. For $99/night in New York City you can NOT go there expecting a lot. My husband and I didn't and were pleasantly surprised when we found a friendly staff, clean room, size was ok (how much time do you spend in your room when you are visiting NY?) The breakfast was good, had bagels, toast bread, muffins, donuts, cereal, bananas, coffee, tea, cappuccino, orange/apple juice...and clean. Yes, the TV didn't work great (we could've asked for that to be fixed, but didn't bother because there were just a few channels that didn't work right). The neighborhood is good and safe, close to the subway, Empire State building, a good central location. There was free internet access in the basement. We didn't use it, but that's a good service.All in all, for that price we were satisfied, would definitely go there again, and wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to friends and family.

Jan 20 2005	Great Value 	We stayed here from 11th January to 18th January 2005 the accomadation was great value for money, rooms were clean and well sized. We had 2 queen beds loads of space the location was perfect this was our 3rd visit to ny and i would stay there again. THUMBS UP !!!

Jan 19 2005	It Stinks! (Literally)	My parents, my wife and I all stayed at the La Quinta Manhattan just after Christmas of 2004, and I'm sorry to say it was a disaster from the moment we checked in. When we arrived, the parking valet told my parents that their RV had too high a clearance for the hotel parking garage, even though my mother had specifically told the reservations agent that they had an oversized vehicle at the time she booked the reservation, and even though the agent had assured them that this would not be a problem. We ended up having to park in a commercial lot several blocks away, at our own expense. The hotel did not reimburse us for the difference between their standard parking charge and what we had to pay to park outside.Once we checked in, we noticed almost immediately that the hotel stank -- literally. The stairways, which we had no choice but to use frequently because of the slow elevators, reeked of garbage and rotten eggs. The hallways on the guest floors had an ever-present odor of mildew, probably because the maids tended to leave carts filled with dirty linens and sheets out in the halls all day and night. And every morning, the guest rooms smelled of the food being cooked for breakfast in the lobby, which at that hour was so crowded that you had to wait in line for about 45 minutes just for a bagel and coffee.The rooms themselves were average-sized for a discount hotel in Manhattan, which is to say, quite small though not impossibly so. The cable TV mostly worked, once you got used to all the complicated steps amd menus you had to go through just to turn it on. The TV-Internet connection was absolutely worthless, and the hotel staff had no idea about how to operate or fix it. The shower water fluctuated between too hot and too cold for the first five minutes, then turned ice-cold and stayed that way. If two people share a room and take their morning showers back-to-back, the second one can forget about having any warm water at all.The maid service was the worst I've ever encountered in New York. On our second day, the maid did not come to service the room until 4:00 pm, even though we had posted the "Maid Service Requested" sign on the door before we went out early that morning. When the maid finally arrived, my wife and I had returned from a day of sightseeing and were attempting to take quick catnap before going out to dinner. When we asked her to come back after 5:00, she brusquely told us that her shift was over at 5:00, and that if we wanted the room cleaned at all, it had to be right that instant. I had to complain to the hotel manager to get them to send a maid after 5:00, and even then, it was done grudgingly. Even my wife, who always makes it a point to tip hotel maids generously, had no problem with not leaving one in this instance.On the plus side, the hotel is centrally located, just a few blocks from the Empire State Building, Herald Square, and Penn Station. The neighborhood is decent, and the price was inexpensive by Manhattan standards. There are a fair number of restaurants nearby, though most of the really good ones are either uptown or below 14th Street. But none of this made up for the poor service, the snails-paced elevators, and the atrocious smells pervading the hallways and stairways above the lobby.In spite of all of this, I have nothing against the La Quinta chain. Two years ago, my wife and I stayed at a La Quinta in New Orleans -- a city where decent and reasonably priced hotels are almost as hard to find as they are in Manhattan -- and found that one to be excellent. I got the impression that La Quinta bought its NYC hotel recently, and is making an effort to bring it up to their standards. But judging from our experience, they have a long, long way to go to make this happen, and I will not be staying at or recommending this particular hotel any time soon.

Jan 13 2005	the only hotel to stay in new york	I found this hotel to be lovely. It has an excellent location, just up the street from Macys and 5 min walk from Times Square. Staff were really nice not like were described in other reviews. Really nice guy there if you need a favour called "persaud", he's very helpful. The lifts were all working and really fast again not like othere reviews that I've read. They seem to have been new ones so maybe they have been changed. Rooms and bathroom are just a tad on the small side but nothing to complain about. You have quite enough room even with 3 people staying in the room with 2 queen beds and luggage! If you are not used to street noise do ask for a room at the back because new york streets are noisy. I'm actually a travel agent and would have no problem in selling this hotel. It's the most reasonable in the city especially for the quality. I have stayed in several 4 star hotels in london and I would consider this hotel a better standard. In my opinon, it's the only place to stay and anyone I spoke to that were staying in the hotel said the same.

Jan 2 2005	Not Bad For The Money	I have to admit for the money we was shocked at how clean this hotel was. It looks like it was recently remodeled. The room was a little small and the tv cut out a couple times, but both elevators worked but they are slow. Parking was only 24 bucks for 40 hours which I thought was reasonable. all in all we give it 2 thumbs up.

Jan 1 2005	not great	Rooms are small, larger rooms smell of Korean food from neighborhood. Heat working ok, but has to be regulated often as it gets too hot. Staff not very helpful. Breakfast is good, but during busy time, not enough tables and chairs. We wouldn't stay here again, unless nothing else was available.

Dec 29 2004	Good for an affordable midtown hotel but don't expect great service	We stayed here in mid December. I travel to NYC every few months on a limited expense account, so I'm always looking for an affordable place. La Quinta had rooms available when the rest of Manhattan seemed booked up due to the holiday season, and the price was good by comparison to other options. Our room was fine; clean, good condition, with OK wifi access; certainly the room was better than other more expensive hotels I've stayed at in NYC. Wifi is definitely "iffy" though so if you must have reliable wifi, try another hotel. Staff were OK but don't expect great service. When we arrived, they had no record of our reservation. My impression is that this isn't a place where a customer can be successful with the staff if the customer gets on their high horse and complains and is demanding; my sense is that the staff would be too happy to tell you to shove it. In our case, we were very polite and smiling and patient, and after about 30 minutes the staff had successfully re-created our reservation at our original rate. Overall I'd stay here again if I could get a great rate, but if something goes wrong, you don't have much leverage with the staff to get anything fixed.

Dec 22 2004	Great Hotel Great Value	My girlfriend and I had a great experience here. We just stayed here last weekend (the weekend before Christmas) and the staff was very helpful and the room was better than expected. I recomend getting a king room, because I've heard the queen rooms are small. It was clean, quiet and the location was incredible. I avoided the breakfast in the morning because it was packed with people and took forever just to get to the coffee maker. Other than that it was quite enjoyable. And the discounted rate on parking was fantastic. I would definately stay here again. And for a rate of 136.00 (with AAA) for the friday and saturday before christmas, you can't beat it!

Dec 19 2004	Extremely rude and incompetent staff	I have never stayed at this hotel, and I would never stay there. I was trying to call a guest staying there, and I got transferred to the room. If this is exemplary of the service provided in the hotel, I can not recommend this hotel.

Nov 19 2004	La Quinta was all right!	We stayed at the La Quinta from Nov 11-14 and found the accomodations to be very satisfactory. We reserved a King bed, non-smoking room and that is what we got. It was clean, pleasant and comfortable. Both elevators are now working, but during check-in and check-out times they can be a little slow. We found the front desk staff and bellman to be very courteous and accomodating. We arrived at 9am on the 11th and they stored our luggage for us until check in time, and arranged for late check-out for us.We booked our room directly on the La Quinta reservation website and had no problems with our accomodations. I overheard two other people at check in complaining that they had booked through a discounter website, and they did not get the accomodation that the discounter had guaranteed. Buyer beware.We would definitely stay here again, the price was reasonable and the location was good.

Oct 25 2004	Truly Awful	My husband and I stayed at La Quinta Manhattan when we returned to NYC for a wedding, having lived in NYC previously for several years. We were used to the prices and small spaces, but nothing prepared us for the horror of this stay. The room we were given was absolutely tiny, with almost too little space for 2 people to be standing up at the same time. (Bed was almost up against the walls on both sides, barely enough room to wiggle sideways into the bathroom. TV set was propped on dresser almost directly at foot of the bed.) The room reeked, and I mean stank, sickeningly and unbelievably of cigarette smoke, as if the room had been an unventilated smoking lounge for the last 50 years (we had asked for a non-smoking room). But get this: the bathroom, which smelled even worse (if that were possible) had a swinging door, with no lock and not even a door handle. In fact, there was no latch of any kind. That's right folks. It was a "swinging door" such as you would find between the kitchen and dining room in a restaurant. This door was right at the head of the right side of the bed, and the toilet was just inside the door. No privacy in there folks, because the person sitting on the toilet behind this door (that did not even entirely fill out the doorjamb) was about 6 inches from the bed, which was the only place where anyone else in the room could be. Try doing your business under those conditions. Lovely. I immediately complained to the front desk, and I was given the room key to another room to look at. Believe it or not, the 2nd room (although slightly bigger) was so indescribably horrible (smelled like a dead body was rotting under the bed) that we promptly went back to the original room. Had there been another room in the city available, we would have left, but there was nowhere to go. I have heard that some rooms at La Quinta are larger than what we stayed in, but we had asked for a non-smoking with a queen size bed, and what we got was revolting, tiny, dirty and miserably hot. Worse, I discovered when I got home that all my stuff smelled like that smoky room and I have had to throw out a garment bag and a cosmetics bag which after repeated cleaning, will not give up that smell. I may also have to throw out my brand new suitcase. So, whatever your options, do yourself a favor and stay away from this place.

Oct 10 2004	broken and smoke	As I arrived at the LaQuinta on my first trip to New York I already had a bad taste in my mouth because when I had called to confirm the reservations I had been told that I would need to pay a different amount for the hotel than I had originally been quoted. Granted, the hotel was a nice building, but the staff was not helpful at all. Also, the famous elevator that I have read about that has been broken is still broken. During my stay the one working elevator only worked approximately twice during my stay of four nights. Also, because I am allergic to smoke I had made certain that I had a non-smoking room and it was a smoking room when I checked in...when I spoke to the staff they were not helpful in switching rooms for me. Yes, the LaQuinta was priced well, but I would definately pick again if I was doing my trip over. As I walked around New York I saw many more hotels that were priced at the same level that I wished I had stayed at. Beware of the LaQuinta unless you want to tolerate broken elevators, rude staff, and a smoky room!

Sep 21 2004	Great location good price	My fiance and I stayed at the La Quinta Manhattan for two nights (9/16 - 9/17) and we both found it very clean and comfortable. Yes, the elevators are a problem - only one is working and it's very slow. However, we were on the 6th floor and we always used the stairs going down so we were able to avoid using it at least half of the time. The breakfast is really great and we found the little guy working in the shop down in the lobby very helpful. The hotel is very close to the Empire State Building - in fact, you get a great view of it from the rooftop bar! Our room was small but still comfortable for the two of us and very clean. Overall, we had a very good experience and I would say that for the money, it was more than we expected.

Sep 18 2004	Comfortable and Clean	My Mom and I stayed at La Quinta for 5 nights in September and we only paid $676 for a double room! For this we received excellent customer service, clean comfortable rooms, and an excellent location! Okay fair enough there was still only one elevator working but we never had to wait that long. I would definitely be staying at this hotel again!

Sep 13 2004 	Great value	Stayed here for a 4 night stay. I selected this hotel because the rates were at least $50 less than any other property in the area (except those with "shared baths"). Paying sub-$100 for midweek in midtown, I was unsure what to expect.But everything was fine. The room was clean and well-serviced. The room size was not huge but not bad, especially for Manhattan: I had a King bed and plenty of room to walk around the room, even with my bags out.There were 2 elevators, but one was under maintenance. That made the waits a bit long but not too terrible.I cannot comment on the service here, since I had no problems that required attention.Typical (free) continental breakfast spread: bagels, cereal, etc.Note that the free wireless is extremely weak, to be expected, I guess, in a 100 year old stone building. I could not get any signal at all, either in my corner room or in the lobby. I was able to get a weak signal from the stairs on my floor, but who wants to work there. However, the phones have data ports and local calls are free.Summary - not the best hotel I've ever stayed at, but a great deal for the price. I would return here anytime cost is a consideration.
Sep 8 2004	Garbage Dump	Terrible Service... Do not stay here.

Sep 3 2004	Terrible service!	This hotel does not understand the meaning of service. When calling to leave a message for a colleague who was (unfortunate enough to be) staying there, I was told "our computers are down, please call back in 15 minutes". I asked if I could leave a manual message, and the desk man said "Actually, it's pretty hectic here; you'd have a better chance if you call back in 10-15 minutes." I agreed to call back. When I called back, I was told the computers were down for at least an hour and I should call back then. I explained that this was an important message and could someone please write it down; my colleague would check the front desk. I was told this was simply not possible. Aug 30 2004 	Try the Holiday Inn....	For a night or two, I guess it is ok. However, if you need to stay longer, forget it! First of all, the rooms are VERY small (think Paris hotels kind of small), and the air conditioning does not work. Secondly, the elevator is a HUGE problem... I am not sure what part of "Do Not Disturb" they had trouble understanding... Anyway, I still have a week to go here, but if I had it to do over, I would not have.... Good luck.
Aug 29 2004	OK-good location	Rooms are small, but clean. Prices are reasonable and it is near the subway. Elevator is small and slow. A reasonable choice for the budget minded.

Aug 29 2004	Awesome Location. Nice rooms!	I just visited NYC this past weekend with family. Aug 24 2004	Good for the price!	Booked this for 2 nights, one night with a LaQuinta return certificate and the second night for $89.00 by calling the LQ Returns customer service number. (We had a roadtrip in between weeks) NEGATIVES Drab and worn lobbyElevator- (but 2nd one working on last day)View- Brick and Fire escapesLocation grimy and dirtyPOSITIVESPriceLocation to Subways & Empire State Buildingwireless internetPS-We never saw any rats the 8 days we were in the city and found every New Yorker to be extremely helpful and friendly! Aug 10 2004	Smallest room imaginable but OKAY Hotel	My wife and I stayed at this hotel July 29th through August 2nd. I selected this hotel based on price and the reviews on this website. This sight was most helpful. Check in was smooth for us, but I immediately noticed another couple switching rooms. Definately a bad sign. The stories about the elevator were true, although the broken one was being worked on. I think they had people pretending to work on it to make the guests feel like something was being done about the problem. I can't imagine it takes months to fix it. Be prewarned, we had issues with the working elevator as well. Room #502We checked into room #502 and couldn't open the door all the way. This was a Queen room, but the bed blocked the door and a small desk hutch area. You have to crawl over the bed to get to the other side because the dresser with the TV hanging over the edge blocks the way. This room was soo small it was funny. My wife couldn't believe it. The bathroom was barely large enough for one person. It was so small it had a shower stall and no tub because the length of the tub would be too long. The bathroom was the size of half a tub. Although the room was small, it was clean and looked like it had been remodeled in the past few years. There were no rats or insects or anything to fear. Rats were a big worry for my wife. As a side note, we later saw lots of them in the subways and Central Park. I guess they're like mosquitos in Texas. While getting settled in the room we noticed it was getting hotter. I walked down the stairs to report this to the front desk and also told them I was suprised by the small room. The lady said they would send someone up to look at the air conditioner and offered to change our rooms the next day. The air was fixed within five minutes and continued to work throughout the night.Room #804We moved to room #804 the next day and were much more comfortable. This was still a Queen room, but there was twice as much room. The bathroom was large enough for two with a full mirror, and lots of counter space. Instead of looking at moldy buildings and grime, we had a slightly better view of the Empire State Building. This room was clean just like the other room. The maid service did a good job as well. They also offer free wi-fi access, which was good because I needed to research activities and look up online subway maps etc. We spent a total of $529 for four nights, which was much cheaper than other hotels during that week. We did book less than two weeks before going, so better deals may have existed earlier. The location was excellent. We could walk or take the subway anywhere. Bryant Park is short walk. Macy's and lots of shopping are even closer. The Empire State Building is even closer. We walked to Times Square once, but found the subway quicker. A cab ride from the hotel to Times Square was about $5. Cab fare from La Guardia to hotel was $35 including tip and $25 to La Guardia from the hotel including tip. Different routes, but we didn't know we were being screwed the first time. Traffic wasn't responsible for the difference. Check your maps ahead of time and help the driver if you need to. Overall: We would stay here again for the convenience and price. Do not check into any room that ends in -02. Good Luck!

Jul 2 2004	Midtown Standard Budget Hotel	We stayed at the La Quinta Inn for 10 days in early-mid June 2004. We chose the midtown location as a good base to explore all Manhattan. The mid streets between 31 and 34 have good subway connections, although the area is crowded and busy.We had a Queen room, which was on the 14th floor. The room was a standard size for a budget hotel in New York. It was clean, the maid service was good, fresh towels, coffee, tea etc and the bed was comfortable and made each day. The shower was fine, iron, ironing board very handy, aircon worked well. The front desk always responded well to our requests. Nothing exceptional but nothing below a standard we would expect from a budget hotel. We had continental breakfast each morning, the dining area is on the ground floor about 8 cafe style tables. It was reasonable, fruit, cereal, toast, teas, fruit juice etc, no yogurt. Again we found this to be as we expected.The main problem was the lift as previous reviews mention as of mid June there was still only 1 working. It is a little inconvenient but it never took that long to arrive and given that it is a very old building and the lifts can only be repaired and not replaced we were grateful one was working at all. Bank machines next door and across the road, nice little Korean pastry shop and excellent Korean restaurants on the same street. Good location for subways uptown and downtown although some of the entrances close at night and it is about a 10 minute walk from Penn station which is the big station and always open.In closing, it is a budget hotel and reviews should fairly assess it in light of the price. We would stay at the hotel again if we got the same low rate including breakfast. If the rate was above say $120 plus tax (excluding July August) we would look elsewhere, but below $120 we felt it was a good deal.

Apr 14 2004	Good Value Good Location -- I'll Be Back	April 8-13,2004 my daughter and I stayed at the LaQuinta Manhattan. Be sure to use the phone in your room before you come downstairs -- you don't want to have to wait on the elevator again, AND the gift shop and front desk won't share their phones. There is a great continental breakfast including bagels, cream cheese, jelly, toast, cereal, donuts, juice, coffee, milk, fresh fruit. Get up early enough to finish breakfast before 10:00 -- they close at 10:00 SHARP -- believe me, if you're eating at 10:00, you will be asked to leave so that they can clean up! The room was clean and comfortable (but the bed was a little too firm for me). Check-in and check-out was fast and courteous. Housekeeping did a great job. My room was on the 7th floor (715) facing 32nd Street. The noise from the garbage trucks woke me every night -- next time I'll ask for a room on the back side of the hotel. The property is located in Little Korea. No matter what time of the day or night, there were always people in the streets (although not super crowded). The street was well light, and I felt safe. The subway stop is half a block away...convenient to everything. If coming back to the hotel late at night, be sure that you don't miss your subway stop....the area south of the hotel (28th street) is kind of creepy at night.

When we pulled down the bedspread in the master bedroom i was nauseated to see dried blood stains on the sheets! we also couldn't open 3 lamps in the living room because the lightbulbs were missing! I immediately called housekeeping to report the issue. 20 minutes later a man knocked on the door and handed meet 2 sheets- he didnt even make the bed! we were so exhausted that we all piled into the kids bedroom and decided to deal with the whole mess in the morning with the front desk. After 3 housekeeping managers all came to inspect the problems they all declared that it was an oversite on someone elses shift. How in the world do they not change the sheets and inspect a room when a new person checks in!!! Then all i kept thinking about was that they only offered me two clean sheets for the bed and not even fresh pillow cases and blankets! Who wants to sleep on the same bedding as the previous guests!!Two days later still no dog bed- we kind of gave up hope, but were not going to let the Hotel ruin our vacation. I explained to her that the show was about to start and that if it would make things easier I would pay someone to pet sit my dog in the room and scratch his belly until i got back. She proceeded to tell me that oh no we don't have any one that would do that! imagine this is a hotel that advertises their pet friendliness!!! 30 minutes into the show ROSA leaves a message on my cell that she entered my room and "captured" my 9lb maltese and that he is in the office downstairs! Needless to say i was hysterical!!! we had to run out of the show which broke my children's hearts! when i ran back to the lobby of the hotel I ran to the front desk begging to see where my pet was abducted to? my dog must have recognized my voice as I heard his crying yelps -we ran behind the mangers desk and found my dog tied in KNOTTED BED SHEETS- tied to the foot of desk!!!( the dog friendly hotel didnt use his leash or even have one of their own!) He was panic stricken - in a state i have never seen in my life!!! Oct 2 2009 	Fantastic comfortable stay however check your bill on checkout!	My wife and I stayed in the Loews Regency for 5 nights for our anniversary. We went to New York and to do the usual sight seeing.I have seen some bad reviews for this hotel, and believe from my experience that they are completely unwarranted. I agree it was expensive (920 for 5 nights) but all hotels in NYC are, so decided I would push the boat out a bit for a nicer stay, and that is exactly what we got. Bear in mind that my wife and I are not rich, travel the world staying in 5 star hotels, or very fussy... but happy with a clean comfortable room.Check in was extremely quick and smooth, and staff were extremely helpful when we asked for directions, taxis or anything else that we requested. We stayed in the superior double room (cheapest on offer), and we thought the room was huge and very clean. The king size was bed was massive, and more comfortable than most beds that I have slept on in any hotel.The decor isn't new or contemporary but the room was clean, as was the spacious bathroom. All bathroom accessories were provided for such as shampoo, soap, body wash, and conditioner. A little dissappointing was the lack of free wifi in the room, but then I'm not on holiday to use the internet. Beside there is a very fast FREE wifi connection in the lobby. As a bit of a fitness freak, I was more than happy with the fitness facilities in the gym, which included a good selection of cardio equipment, as well as weights and gym mats.The walls in hotel are slightly too thin as you can hear noise from the corridors, but it isn't that bad. I thought the locaion was excellent, a couple of blocks from Central Park, a block away from the closest subway which goes straight to Times Square, Spring Street, Brooklyn Bridge. But to be honest you can pretty much walk everywhere from the hotel... approx 15mins to Times Sq. There are also loads of Cafes and restaurants in the area for good breakfasts or dinner.As for the bill... make sure you check it and get a copy when you leave. We never use the minibar at any hotel due to the extortionate prices. On checkout they tried to charge us for minibar usage, but could not tell us what it was we had drunk. When we said we did not use they minibar they assured us that the bill would be corrected. However on our return to England I found a charge of $7.04 on my card from the hotel, for drinking a can of coke from the minibar. It took four emails to the hotel to get the money back. As for NYC... it's a fantastic city for sightseeing, eating and shoppping. Subway is cheap and quick if you don't want to walk, but I wouldn't advise using it after 10pm. Have breakfast at Balthazar, and eat dinner at Public. Also if you want to get a good view... Rockerfeller is much better than the Empire State Building.

Check with the reservation desk on Monday @ 3PM and find-out that the new rooms are not ready yet. Go up to the old rooms and find that we have been locked-out. Ask to speak to the manager -- clerk goes to a room behind the reservation desk and comes back a few minutes later -- told person who has one of the new rooms has not checked-out yet -- after much back and forth "reassigned" a single room with two bedrooms.Professionalism  A member of staff mistook my friends wife as part of the hotels housekeeping staff and admonished her for drinking the coffee that is made available in each guests room.Amenities  Furniture and baseboards shopworn; stain in one of the bedspreads; window left open and hard to close because of a bent metal frame plus many years of oxidation.

Aug 26 2009 	"Luxury deals are available"	Contrary to some recent reports, I have little but praise for the Loews Regency Hotel NYC.I booked a 2 bedroom suite in January via Magellan Vacations, at a cost of USD 640.00 per night. The room was circa 1300 square feet, and included a guest washroom/WC, kitchen area, sitting room/dining room c/w 50" Plasma, two large bedrooms c/w 32" LCD's and an entrance lobby. The room allocated (728) was a corner location, with views down Park Av and 61st St.We arranged for airport transfer via Capricorn Limousines (aligned to the hotel) and the whole transfer experience was seamless. Check In was fast and professional, as was the delivery of our luggage. The location of the hotel, 2/3 blocks from Bloomingdales, Central park and 5th Avenue is perfect for those with only a few days to explore the city.In line with many NYC hotels, it is important to impose yourself at the offset. Generous tipping upon arrival invariably ensures a 'smoother' experience, and though not obligatory, is nevertheless expected in an establishment of this calibre. I have previously stayed at the Waldorf Towers and Parker Meridian, and both provide the same outcome.Our rooms were spotless, and the lemonade in the lobby a welcome relief in the heat of the day.A special thanks to Lisa for her kindness in making an unforgettable stay for the girls.

Aug 13 2009 	Elegant with some inconveniences	The lobby is bustling with ladies wearing hats, business men and a few tourists. The lobby bathroom has complimentary amenities and is gorgeous. Rooms are spacious, comfortable. Very pet-friendly. Do beware, however. Internet is $16 for 24 hours, and they have an awkward policy that charges from noon to noon. This means that if you purchase internet at 11am you will have an hour and need to pay another $16. Very illogical. We found the front desk staff to be somewhat rude and unhelpful at times. The hotel is very elegant, but I would expect higher service for the price. Do check out The Library, the hotels restaurant, which is nice and has good food.

Aug 11 2009 	Loews Regency: Getting Tired and Sad	I've been to the Loews Regency many times over the past decade and I'm sorry to report that it's not really the same hotel anymore. The feel of the hotel has changed: from a high-end hotel that catered to a well-traveled and probably demanding clientele (film people, business people, upper tier travelers, diplomats) to, well, a pricier tourist hotel that seems to be overrun with European and Australian tourists. And while you can put up with a snooty attitude when the rest of the hotel balances it out, when that balance doesn't exist, snooty pretty quickly turns into sneery, which leads to annoyance. Whereas the rooms used to be spotless, ours had a fairly large black stain on the floor. The beds were comfortable enough, but they're also starting to show their age--especially when you compare them to Westin's comfy beds, or the pillowtops that a lot of higher-end hotels have now. Other small things. The "do not disturb" sign was missing, as was the tag to hang on your door if you wanted breakfast. And what happened to my free shoe shine? Unfortunately, this seems to be business as usual for Loews. I used to stay at the Loews Santa Monica fairly often, until it too began to get run down and your fellow travelers were all excited about "seein' the movie and tee vee stars." Blech.Sorry Loews Regency. Give me a call when you renovate.

Jun 27 2009 	A Customer service nightmare	I stayed one night at the Loews Regency New York and I will never make that mistake again. They were perfunctory in every respect. I called and was connected to housekeeping which began what I can only describe as a farce for the next three weeks. I ultimately received the dress after two weeks of phone calls (I honestly believe, I am sorry to say, that someone in housekeeping had claimed my dress for herself and was made to bring it back to work). I paid for shipping and received the dress in ridiculous condition. There were six deliberately made burn marks in it, rips, tears, and some of the seams were shredded. When I called to complain, the manager on duty disconnected me "accidentally", then re-directed me back to the same woman in housekeeping with whom I had already dealt. She left me a voice mail telling me that the dress was sent to me in perfect condition. Since the packaging in which it was sent was completely intact and still is, this is impossible. Business ethics are not present at this hotel. I am now out the price of the dress, the cost of shipping, the expense of the phone calls, and my time. May 24 2009 	Beyond expectations	I was pleasantly surprised with this hotel. Everything was as described in the ads. May 6 2009 	How To Handle A Problem	We reserved a very comfortable and well-appointed 2-bedroom suite at the Park Avenue Loews Regency New York for a weekend beginning May 1, three nights at $793 a night. Several times we discussed returning again to use the same space. But everything changed Sunday evening. The adjoining suite erupted in an extremely noisy party, every shouted word of which filled the living room of our suite. We called Guest Services and said we could not use our living room and please have the party quieted down. Nothing happened. For the remainder of Sunday we abandoned the living room of the suite, as we had no choice but to confine ourselves to the most distant bedroom. The next morning, paying my $2600 bill at checkout, I went over it all again, and was assured that I would soon be contacted by Management. Subsequently the Front Desk Manager telephoned me with a very sincere apology, and volunteered an adjustment amount to my bill that clearly reflected that they took the situation very seriously. We'll go back soon.

May 5 2009 	Not worth it..snooty staff that act like they own Park Ave.!!	Im a pretty regular travelor and have been to many hotels in my day, and was very excited for my newborn's first trip to NYC and first hotel stay of his life! Based on reviews, Loews seemed to be the best of all worlds, but I was quite surprised to find that the Regency, NYC lacked in all of those respects. Sure enough, they gave me a room w/ a kitchenette, but didnt charge me for it..bonus, but not sure what the deal was. I requested a crib upon arrival, and when I got there at 6:30pm, we were taken up to the room by an excellent bellman, but the crib wasnt there yet. When i asked the bellman if I should call downstairs to get it, he said that he was going to take care of it. When we returned from dinner around 10pm with my child sleeping in my arms, still no crib! We called downstairs and they finally came by 11:30 to assemble the crib, which took a half hour, while my child slept on our bed. Next, my room key deactivated twice and I couldn't get into the room, and you would think by the second time, they would have sincerely apologized, but the lady at the front desk barely looked me in the eye, let alone apologized. My wife ordered room service one night, and I know that NYC prices are up there, but she got a grilled cheese and a side salad, which came out to $58...come on! We stayed in a huge two room suite overlooking Park Ave. . 1100 sq. ft. with 3 closets and 1 1/2 baths, refrigerator and microwave. Sofa bed was useable but in poor shape, but the two rollaways the hotel provided were perfect for the kids. The room was on special discount via Leows hotels and offered best value I found in NYC--two small rooms at nearby Sheraton or Hilton would have cost more and provided half the space.The neighborhood is the perfect location for a nyc trip. Easy access via Park Ave. and great location to Central Park (2 blocks) & Bloomingdales, Madison & Fifth Ave. shopping all within easy walking distance of a few blocks. One block east to Lexington Ave (or two blocks east to Third Ave.) and there are a host of deli and supermarket choices, burger joints or fine dining--whatever you prefer. We visited the "top of the rock" for views of the city from the top of Rockefeller Center...The "Rock" is definitely a "tourist" destination, but if you like looking down on the city, the views are tremendous and there were no lines. The observation areas are very clean and the glass walls around the observation deck don't obstruct views like the screens/fences surrounding the Empire State Building. We also tried the circle-line double decker bus downtown tour. We picked up the bus at central park...just a few blocks from the hotel. The kids loved that as well...and they liked hopping off and back on a different bus at various stops. Two tour guides were great, one was a cynical jerk, but hey it's NYC and you never know what you're gonna get. The great thing about the buses is that you can hop off at any time.Cab rides even from downtown were never more than 10-12 dollars and there is easy access to the hotel. Subway entrances are also just a few blocks away.Regency Hotel went out of the way to make our stay enjoyable--they provided umbrellas from the doorman if it was raining. free coffee (delicious) in the lobby in a.m. and free lemonade in the afternoon. The housekeeping staff provided everything we needed right away. It's been a long time since I stayed in NYC and felt welcomed and not simply like I was being "processed" through the hotel system. The neighborhood also felt safe and clean. This will definitely be our hotel of choice for future visits.

Aug 25 2007 	Dependable 4-star Great location.	We stay here about once or twice a year. Prices are generally competitive for New York- this time I paid just over $420 net per night. Rooms are clean and quiet, location couldn't be better, and if you join Loews First, you can generally get an upgrade to next larger/better room/suite. Restaurants are great for breakfast, lunch, dinner, and after dinner. But I usually want breakfast before they open. In that case, walk one block over (right out of hotel, right on 60th, right on Madison) and eat at Viande Coffee Shop. Fast basic food and they must open for business at dawn- I've never arrived "too early" for a quick hearty breakfast.

Aug 12 2007 	Good location Adequate room	My husband and I stayed 3 nights and had a good experience. The staff was well trained, the location good and the room, although not special, met our needs.Nice location to get to shopping, but I would not recommend dining in the restaurant. I wanted a beverage one evening and got a mini can of diet coke for a whopping $7. The bowls of free M & M's almost made up for it...but not quite!

Aug 10 2007 	Very nice employees but a disappointment	We have just returned from a week at the Regency. The hotel was a very big disappointment. First, let me say I have been to NY several times and know that the room standards in New York are sometimes below other hotels in other parts of the country, but based on the reviews and our vacation club recommendations we booked a luxury room with two double beds. Upon arrival, I found the staff very very friendly. They had toys for my kids and were very courteous to my wife and I. The hotel is well off the tourist path and you might need to give the taxi driver the cross streets, since some did not know where the regency was located (park and 61st). Since the hotel is away from the hot spots, the noise from "the city that never sleeps" does not keep you awake. OK, now for the bad stuff. We were given a room on the third floor. When the hotel elevator doors open to this floor we were greeted with the great smell of ciggarette smoke. We are not talking about a light smell, but one that gives you the impression that this floor has seen years of smoke. Keep in mind, Im a ex-smoker and normally the smell does not bother me, but wow. Once we got to our room, we found it very large (by NY standards) with two double beds as promised along with a good size bathroom and a small kitchen net. You can tell the rooms have been occupied a lot by the amount of stains in the carpet. I always get very paranoid by the color of some of the stains.... Once i sat down on the bed, I noticed a very very strong vomit odor coming from the top right side of the bed. I immediately called down and was told that someone will be up soon. Within 2 mins, a maid had come to change the sheets. I asked for another room, but was told that there were none available until tomorrow. The following day, my wife was too scared to change rooms in fear that the new one would be worst. For anyone traveling with kids, sometimes you need things in the night to help with the boredom. One thing might be a movie on the on demand television. Well on the first night we tried to use this service we were billed, but no movie played. We, again, had to call the front desk to get the charge removed from our bill and were told the on demand service is not working in the hotel. We also found out our mini bar was missing...even though we had a mini bar key...lol. This meant that we had to order room service for a soft drink. (there were no machines in the hotel and no outside vendors in this area). I will say, even though we called down to the front desk more then I have ever done before, I can tell you the staff were never short with us and were very patient. As someone who likes to travel, I can tell you it would take a lot for me to stay at this hotel again.

Jul 1 2007 	Great hotel - very pet friendly	Stayed at the Regency on business in April for four nights. My husband and small dog came along. Loews is great with pets. Our room was at the end of the hall, which is great when you have a pet and was very spacious. They provided dog bowls and treats and we were allowed to leave our dog in the room unattended. Our room was spotless, it is obvious that the hotel is very well maintained. Room service the three or four times we ordered it was delivered promptly and the food was of very high quality. There are three reasons that I give this hotel a 4 rather than a 5. First, it's pricey, even by New York standards. I believe our double room was $479 per night. Second, if you are scouting this hotel for tourism, the location is not supurb, it is somewhat far from the major tourist areas. It is, however, perfect for the Lex and Park area. Lastly, it's an older hotel and the soundproofing is not very good. It is a loud place, which is bothersome in the mornings if you are attempting to sleep in.Overall, I'd definitely return, mostly due to their wonderful treatment of pets.

Jun 13 2007 	Very pleasant stay	This was a very nice place to stay! Just a couple of blocks from Madison Ave. and Central Park. 3 of us stayed in a suite which had a kitchenette, living room, king bedroom and 2 bathrooms, and plenty of closet space!!!! The room was clean and tastefully decorated. No clutter! The bathrooms were a little small but fine enough. The bedding was clean and very comfortable!!! the couch was cushy and comfy as was the cot they brought in for one of us. The extra blankets they brought in were soft and when we requested them, they had just come out of the dryeer and were warm:) The housekeeping cleaned up the bathrooms daily which was nice. The towels were clean(I've been to hotels where the towels were not!) Even though the mini bar was pricey, we still enjoyed some of it:) We didn't eat in the restaurant but did have lunch in the Library, which was nice, very tasty food! Room service was pricey, the food was good but nothing special. Your best bet would be to hit up a local grocery. The hotel staff including the housekeeping, maintenance and doormen were very friendly. We were on the 10th floor near the elevator which we did hear the noise from that, but it wasn't that bad and we had no problems getting to sleep after shopping all day!!! This is a pet friendly hotel and we noticed several guests had dogs, but we never heard any barking and the place didn't smell at all of pets. We plan to stay again because of the closeness to Madison Ave and because it was such a pleasant stay!

Jun 4 2007 	Regency aims to please!	Just got back from a weekend at the Regency in NYC and it was a wonderful experience. I went with my significant other and my daughter. May 29 2007 	Excellent location - close to the Park between shopping and arts	I can't say enough how wonderful The Regency was. We stayed during Memorial Day weekend. Apr 4 2007 	The Regency is a excellent choice in NY	Excellent location for Park Ave , 5th Ave etc., friendly staff, classic oversized rooms, and a terrific service. The afternoon tea at the Library is the best way to rest after a busy day.

Mar 15 2007	Great hotel	We stay at this hotel on an annual basis for with our Show dog for the Westminster Kennel CLub dog show at Madision Square Gardens each feb, The staff is very friendly, welcomes us back each year and our precious poochies, Loews truly does love PETS. Feb 17 2007 	Terrific Spot	My husband stays here for business one or two nights at a time, about 8 times a year. He travels weekly across the US so he's been in a lot of hotels. Jan 31 2007 	Great stay at the Loews Regency	I am sitting in my bed at the Regency as I write this review :)My trip to NYC started in another hotel, which was pretty dirty. I was ready to get the heck out of that property and over to the Regency!Check-in was fast, even though there was an error in my reservation which was NOT the hotels fault.I stopped by the concierge to ask a few questions. They were funny and both had kind eyes. That sounds funny, but you know you can just feel when someone is genuinely nice.I head up to my room and was so happy when I walked in! I believe my room is a standard room. It is decorated in a minimalist decor, which I love. Loads of space, lots of counter space, 2 closets and large tub. The 'desk' is really a marble counter that extends the full width of the room. There is a large plasma TV, stereo, and Bloom bath products.The robe is great... and I never bother with robes. It is silk with a soft terry lining. Water pressure is excellent. Bed is HARD. I have a Select Comfort at home and generally I find hotel beds to be hard, but this one is really firm. Beautiful linens.This room is SPOTLESS. Possibly one of the cleanest I have ever been in (out of hundreds).I don't usually let anyone in the room once I check in... no housekeeping, no room service, no turn down. I just don't like it.Today housekeeping was in the neighboring room when I got back (1pm). The lady practically begged for me to let her clean my room. I went ahead and let her. She was just the nicest lady... very concerned for the guests in her rooms. Again, it did not seem fake. I tipped her very well, but I don't really think she was expecting it. Really. I met a guy (in a suit) in the elevator that was talking to the cleaning staff and I asked him what he does at the hotel... he INSPECTS the rooms after they are cleaned! Maybe that's why they are so spotless.The mini-bar is not electronic, so I was able to run down to Whole Foods and buy food for my whole stay and stick it in the fridge. Great... I hate eating out.There is a 24 hour mini-mart just around the corner for last minute purchases. Free hot chocolate (very rich) was at the elevator each evening, apples too.The doorman were really very nice as I walked in and out during the past few days. I attended a Departures magazine presentation yesterday and they were talking about 5,6 and 7 star (YES!) hotels. They were trying to explain to us the values of the very rich.Well, I am probably one of the least demanding travelers... I need a good location and I expect a clean, clean room, good amenities, services and quality furnishings. This hotel meets all my simple requirements Genuinely nice employees are a bonus!I hope I get to stay here again.

Jan 9 2007	Tired Looking Hotel Passing off as Luxury - Good Location	This hotel is very nicely located on 61st street at Park Avenue - easy walking or subway distance to most places in Manhattan.The lobby is attractive, large and inviting. I don't know the reason but a renovation is in order.I don't really have any complaints about the hotel or service but I didn't deem this as luxury.The bathroom was fairly large but again needed a facelift. Oct 17 2006	Everything about this hotel is fabulous	This hotel is one of the best in New York. Very friendly staff, from the doormen to the concierge!! Beautiful comfortable beds.Close to everything!

Sep 23 2006 	The Regency On Park Avenue is good but a boost is needed	I've stayed at The Regency On Park Avenue too many times to count, and I've always enjoyed the hotel, even with minor quibbles. My stays are the result of business trips. I've noticed that Loew's, which owns the hotel, has placed its name in a more prominent place alongside the words The Regency Hotel. This month my stay was for one night, over Thursday and Friday,I rarely think of Loew's as a luxury-oriented chain, and I think that's the reason things are not as terrific as they once were at The Regency.The bathroom toiletries are less deluxe; seemingly Loew's generic; whereas The Regency used to provide high-end toiletries. The towels are still good; the bath towel is especially fluffy and large.I was stunned to hear, at around 8 a.m. Friday morning, women from Housekeeping knocking on doors on my floor. That's absurd and much too early. This never happened as recently as 2005. And it should not happen at all. The woman tapped on my door and I ignored it. She even tried the door, but the extra "chain-like" security catch was linked, so she couldn't get in.The Reception Desk personnel were friendly, but not quite deluxe. I did not avail myself of the Concierge. The various uniformed gentlemen at the front door were always friendly and provided greetings. They were a little understaffed on Friday afternoon when I needed to get a cab to the airport.The bed was good; the air conditioning/heat fan system worked well. The room was quiet, clean, and pleasant. It was a standard room consisting of a very large and comfortable bed, crisp sheets, dresser, mini-bar (yes, nuttily overpriced), desk, and good size closet. The carpet was fine, although a cosmetic cleaning wouldn't hurt. The view out my 12th floor window was pleasing. I was away from Park Avenue, so the silence was golden. My biggest complaint was with Room Service, which actually blamed a longer waiting period on - get this - the fact that it was raining outside. What? Were they sending out for the food? Food was promised in one hour - ridiculous since the kitchen knows the menu and the foodstuffs are on the premesis. I've always found 30 minutes to be the norm at high-end hotels. I ordered Room Service at around 9:30 p.m.As for the food, well it failed. I ordered a bacon and turkey club sandwich, but it really wasn't a club sandwich at all, but two very large slices of toasted Italian bread with the dull and lifeless sandwich items within. The bread was too thin, thus it was hardish. The sandwich was cut in two sections and was more a panini than a club. My French fries were coolish. Is it so difficult to provide HOT French fries. And I hate cold or cool French fries. The sorbet was fine, well-chilled in a bowl set over ice; therefore it didn't melt as I hate my entree. The chicken soup was good, but not plentiful. And, of course, there was the absurd "delivery fee," which I have found, still find, and always will find offensive. Are we able to go down and get the food ourselves? It isn't called ROOM SERVICE for nothing. This fee is actually an insult. I don't mind the normal 16%, 17%, or 18% tip fee - you live with it, but this delivery fee is so tacky.The Regency has a great location with quick steps to Madison or Fifth Avenue. One big problem is that if you want your own "corner store" or "deli" service, you won't fnd any along this stretch of Park Avenue or even a block up on Madison. I tried. You'll need to walk over to Lexington or maybe Third. The shops on Madison begin their high-end run, with Barney's anchoring a corner. The Regency is around 62nd Street and Park.Look, I consider myself fortunate that my work allows me stay in deluxe hotels. There are people who never even travel, let alone get to stay so well around the country. But, hotels that promise luxury need to live up to that claim. The Regency is slipping. My room was clean and pleasant. But overall, the hotel itself needs a little boost. High-end means luxury. And that's what I used to expect and once received from The Regency. It should make a return. Better toiletries in the bathroom would be a start. This stay was average, not wonderful. Definitely not Four Seasons style.

Jan 19 2006 	My favourite hotel	The Regency is my favourite hotel anywherre, I've stayed there four times and rate it very highly. Jan 8 2006	Great Hotel	The Regency might be one of the best in city and possibly the country. The rooms and service were very good. We would definitely stay there again.

Dec 11 2005 	Pretty good hotel but the service charge - ouch!	Stayed there for 3 nights. You don't expect any view at that location and there wasn't. And in the middle of NY city you don't expect tranquility either from the traffic or the heating / aircon. The room was very big (don't know if it's standard), bathroom didn't feel too small espeically with it's separate shower - the TV was a curiousity considering reception there is terrible. Housekeeping is excellent. The bed is fanstastic.Food is neither good nor reasonably priced and neither is room service at all fast. And yes, the 21% service charge, and $5 per person 'delivery charge', and of course the waiters still expect a cash tip on top... Although they try hard there's always something missing in the order, and since the simplest things take at least half an hour to arrive you just have to give up. I had a chilled seafood salad in my room - a whole, shelled lobster, 3 giant prawns (still 'shrimps') which were tasteless, and a mountain of shelled crab and salad. For a couple of dollars less I ordered the lobster salad in the Library, and you get half a lobster and a few leaves! And don't have the Amish chicken - it's truly uptight!Wired internet is a mystery, and I hooked up to an unsecured wireless connection - perhaps thats why my laptop isn't working now.The location is excellent for shopping, central park, museums and art galleries. Overall its a pretty good hotel - I'm just glad I was on expenses, and don't bother with the food.

Oct 26 2005	Not luxury but good first class	Location is the best in NY. Hotel is very nice first class hotel; Home-away-home -type accommodation. House keeping is keeping the rooms very clean. Aug 8 2005	First time there we loved it	Stayed at the Regency for the first time for three nights in late July, and it was great. Aug 4 2005	New Year at the Regency	I stayed at the Regency Hotel in Dec 04 and stayed for the new year celebrations. The hotel is set in an excellent location, literally a couple of minutes walk from bloomingdales and a subway station. Jul 14 2005	Elegance on the East Side	My parent's 60th wedding anniversary was the occasion for our gathering at the Regency. We were all treated like kings, queens, princes and princesses. The service was excellent. The only slip was needing to get out room re-keyed when our keys no longer worked for some inexplicable reason. The hotel staff is very attentive and friendly, and make you feel like you belong there and are not just a visitor. Overall the hotel is rather expensive and the restaurant was very pricey, so we only had one breakfast there. There were some reasonable eateries in the area, so it wasn't too hard to keep within a budget. However, the upper east side and the Regency is not the place to stay if you are on a tight budget. It is a great place to stay for a special occasion. We were all very happy with the hotel. My parents received complimentary Mumms champagne and some sweets. The location was good for shopping, Central Park jog or walk, and close enough to 5th Ave and midtown to get there by walking or quick cab ride. My travel agent warned that the older NY hotels can be "tired", but that was not at all the case with the Regency. The whole hotel was well appointed and furnished. Since we had kids, our only room choice was a double/double. The size of our room was fine for four people with two closets, a kitchette, table and chairs and an upholstered sitting chair. I got to see the rooms with a king bed, and thought they were great and plenty big for two adults (i.e. leave the kids at home). I don't think this hotel has much to offer in terms of view rooms; we looked out over some rooftops. Nonetheless, the Regency is a well known and well-respected hotel, frequented by many celebs and "power" people. Consider it for a classic NY experience.

May 24 2005	Attention deficit disorder	Maybe we got them at the wrong time, but the staff members at the Regency were not on their game when we stayed at this hotel.There were numerous times during our 5 day visit that we were not greeted upon arrival, or addressed as we left. I had to summon a cab for my family on four separate occasions. Every room on our floor had a newspaper at its door, every day. We got a newspaper at the door on two mornings. Bath robes? We lacked one, and requested it. The robe was delivered, and then retrieved the next day, without a replacement. I didn't think it was worth a $10 daily tip to get the thing back.Internet access is about $20 a day, and no one on site was able to explain the hookup protocols.The employees were kind and polite, and the majority spoke English and Spanish fluently.The room was well kept, and maid service was very good.The restaurant ("The Library")serves an excellent breakfast, and the wait staff is completely attentive. The hostess provides free newspapers including foreign and domestic. (She was the most caring and competent hostess that I've EVER met in New York, in 25 years of traveling there.)I recommend the restaurant unhesitatingly. May 24 2005	Great location-- we never left the Upper East side.	We enjoyed the hotel and staff once our issues were ironed out at check in. At 5:00 PM, we returned a third time only to be told that our room had been overbooked and that we would be moved to an inferior room that would include about a $25.00 daily rate reduction from $365.00 a day to $339. per day The manager on duty was very helpful and willing to correct our room problem when we spoke with him. He reduced our total stay to the reduced rate of $319.00/daily that we later booked as a weekend rate. He also arranged for a room upgrade since we belong to Loew's First. We spent one night in the smaller overbooked room and the remainder of the trip in a much nicer room at the lower daily rate of $319.00 per day. The room was very large for NYC. The 2 closets were perfect-- one was a walk in closet with a small safe. There are about 3 or 4 different places to sit in the room, although the bathroom had very limited space. We loved everything about the room except the 20+% rate added to the laundry bill that I was not aware of when I discussed the expense of steaming a veil and formal dress while at the hotel. Even with those two issues, the hotel is perfect for vacationers. I noticed lots of pets around the property that belonged to guests. It was cute. We would stay there again but we try to stay somewhere different each trip to the city. We have stayed at the Royalton and the Park Central back in the early 80's. Then in the mid 80's, we stayed at the Shoreham and the St. Regis Hotel. We have stayed at the Paramount, Parker Meridian and the Barbazon in the early 90's. All hotels offer something to meet the expectation for each visitor's taste. Check out this hotel or any of the others listed as well. All come highly suggested.

Mar 23 2005	the best so far	weve stayed in new york five times and so far this has been the best hotel yet. Staff are very friendly and curtious. Room service very good, clean and tidy and nice spacious rooms. would definately go back again

Jan 9 2005	Wonderful as usual at the Regency	We are frequent visitors to New York City and like to stay in modern, luxury hotels that are in nice, convenient locations. Often we travel with our 14 year old daughter and our beloved 4 year old terrier, so we are looking for places that are welcoming to kids and dogs! The Regency fits the bill on all counts. Our last visit was over the Christmas holiday. We arrived on Christmas eve and stayed for three nights. We had a deluxe luxury king which turned out to be one of the largest rooms I have ever stayed in in the city. The furnishings were tasteful and classically modern, sophisticated but not cold. There were plenty of places to store clothes (and we travel with a lot), books, etc. The room had a large desk, table and small banquette, and in another area, a comfortable chair with a great reading lamp.The bathroom was not particularly large, but well appointed with plenty of counter space. It also contained a large tub and separate shower stall with European fixtures - great for us since by husband likes to bathe and I shower.Although quite full, the hotel staff couldn't have been nicer, although the service was a bit slow in the smaller library like cafe where we ate breakfast.There is also a great fitness facility at the hotel, free to guests. If that is important to you, than this one does a good job of providing many extras (yoga mats, fitness balls, etc.) that you don't get in all hotels.We have stayed here a number of times and will definitely return again.

Dec 14 2004	Decent but not great	Got a luxury king room with Park Ave view. The lobby was nice and intimate but the elevators were very dark and unpleasant. Dec 13 2004	Could do with a make-over!	For my daughters 18th, I thought a trip to New York and to top it all we would stay in a lovely hotel. I chose the Regency, Not a good move! I was told the hotel was full, but I persisted and was offered another. This was an improvement but the carpet had some very bad stains and a tiny bathroom, it just looked dark and tied. Dec 5 2004	Very Pleasant Stay	My husband and I stayed at the Regency Dec 1 through 3, 2004. Our room was very nice and the staff could not have been more accomodating. We usually stay on the west side but found that this location was very convenient. We would stay here again.

Dec 2 2004	A wonderful Thanksgiving	Stayed at the Regency for 5 nights over Thanksgiving weekend. Had a lovely, large room, well designed and well maintained.
